title: 114_hr4635
content: The Act titled "Servicemembers and Veterans Prescription Drug Safety Act of 2016" establishes a Prescription Drug Take-Back Program for members of the Armed Forces and their dependents. The Act defines terms such as covered beneficiary, covered controlled substance, dependent, and eligible person, including members of the Armed Forces and individuals receiving retired pay under title 10. The Act defines terms related to members of the Armed Forces and individuals receiving retired pay under title 10, United States Code. The Secretary and the Attorney General are required to jointly carry out a program established under subsection (b)(1). The program includes covered beneficiaries, dependents, and individuals lawfully entitled to dispose of property of those in possession of covered controlled substances for personal use. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary and the Attorney General shall jointly carry out a program under which eligible persons may deliver covered controlled substances for disposal at specified facilities. The program allows for delivery of controlled substances to designated facilities and persons, regardless of authorization requirements under the Controlled Substances Act. The Secretary and the Attorney General will develop guidelines to prevent abuse of controlled substances delivered under the program. Regulations must be prescribed within a year of the Act's enactment, and the program must be fully implemented within a year of the regulations being prescribed. SEC. 3. PRESCRIPTION DRUG TAKE-BACK PROGRAM FOR VETERANS AND THEIR DEPENDENTS. In this section, "covered controlled substance" refers to specific controlled substances listed in the Controlled Substances Act. An "eligible person" includes veterans, their spouses receiving medical services, dependents receiving medical services, and individuals receiving medical services at a VA facility. The Department of Veterans Affairs, along with individuals authorized to dispose of property of eligible persons, are involved in a program established by the Secretary to carry out activities related to covered controlled substances. The term "veteran" is defined as per section 101 of title 38, United States Code. The Controlled Substances Act allows eligible individuals to deliver covered controlled substances for disposal at specified facilities and by designated persons. The Secretary and the Attorney General will determine where these substances can be delivered under the program to prevent abuse. The Secretary and the Attorney General will develop guidelines to prevent diversion of controlled substances under the program. Regulations must be prescribed within a year of the Act's enactment, and the program must be fully implemented within a year of the regulations being prescribed.
